comments.commentBody: I am certain that the polls were accurate in expecting a solid Clinton win.  I am also convinced that FBI Director James Comey won the election for Trump/GOP but no one seems to care one way or the other.  It's almost as if it never happened, just a little glitch in politics-as-usual, a bit of personal bad judgement.  I felt the bottom fall out of the Clinton campaign the moment I read the news. Was I alone?

It is obvious that there are conflicts and it is also obvious that he will do absolutely nothing to mitigate those conflicts, as there is no consequence to him.  If there is a possible consequence, someone needs to articulate what it is, because all I see is 4 years of saying "Aw sheesh, Donald, c'mon, will you tell us everything today?  Still no?  Jeepers, Donald..."

1. Keep his kids AND his son-in-law out of the Situation Room and out of all White House Daily Briefings, etc.
2. He is remiss if he doesn't set up an HONEST blind trust. Carter did it for a small peanut business. Trump has financial deals all over his now very polluted planet.
3. Where are his tax returns?
4. Where are Melania's immigration papers? Her naturalization papers?

He's all about "show me the money." I want to know the person in the White House is operating with candor not rancor.
Maybe had the media spent some time publishing such information early on in the campaign instead of hanging on Trumps tweets he wouldn't be president.

As a retired IRS agent, I would be very interested in monitoriing the future course of the current IRS audits for Trump and his businesses. That has not been discussed since this miserable election concluded. Who'd have thought that a president of the United States would under audit by the IRS?

Will IRS be pressured to wind up the audits in short order? Will the results be a "no-change" (favorable to the taxpayer)? Sadly, if they know what's good for them, the agents conducting the audits will likely fold. Let's keep a watch NYT.

Where is Jason Chaffetz on the ethics issues with Trump?

He was investigating Hillary Clinton if she looked at someone sideways, but when there are real serious conflicts of interest and most likely serious ethics violation's, Jason Chaffetz is nowhere to be heard or found.

Trump and Putin talked about establishing oligarchs in the U.S. but then Putin mentioned the old status of the czar. Under pure czardom everything and everybody in Russia was the personal property of the czar.
And that's when Trump's eyes lit up!

Trump's only interest is self-interest; his deepest emotion greed.  Everything else is a distant second and he will conduct his personal and public affairs in his own interest above all. He won't repeat the failure of previous presidents to exploit the office for maximum gain. There is no interest save self-interest.

“It’s very unlikely Mr. Trump will sell his businesses or put them into a blind trust.”

We’ll soon find out if there is one set of rules for the Trumps and another set of rules for other presidents and their families?

With Jared Kushner, his son-in-law, slated to become a security-cleared advisor to President Trump, it’s hard to see any opacity between the Trump White House and Trump businesses, especially its international components, run by Trump’s children.

So will Trump’s promise to “Make America Great Again” mean he will “Make Trump Even Greater” or does it necessarily mean selling his businesses to avoid any conflicts of interests? As his pal’s “National Enquirer” magazine used to ask, “Enquiring minds want to know?" Pray tell, Mr. President-elect?
This one is very easy to figure out.  It's called common sense.

Your article describes precisely the parameters of the future Presidential desition making. It is the framework of impeachment.

Since Trump wants his children with security clearance and, "to take over" his business, the future President is adding more conflict of interest to the original ones.

We should not forget the next President will have the Congress, the Attorney General and maybe, a political Supreme Court.

I hope I am wrong because otherwise, it will be very difficult to restore public trust in our democratic institutions, after the catastrophe.

Your editorial clearly delineated issues which are deeply troubling. We need to be vigilant and hold Trump accountable for any actions which put personal gain above that of the nation.  It will be difficult to do so because, Trump has been resistant to the kinds of transparency (release of tax returns, etc,) which would permit such scrutiny. It is more important than ever to have a robust free press to help speak truth to power and to hold the administration accountable.
Rail away, boys. Trump will sit in his tower and show you his short middle digit.

I think the odds pretty low that a multi-billionaire will take actions in office for his own financial gain. He has already gained pretty much all there is to get financially. Also, why the distinction between public good and personal financial gain? I daresay there are plenty of actions that result in both, and plenty that result in neither.

He promised to release his tax returns once the IRS audit was complete.

Never forget this. Keep asking for his tax returns. Don't let him off the hook.

Now you write about this?!?!?! I have been asking NY Times writers to say something about the "yuge" conflict of interest that swirls around every decision he will make in the Oval Office. His businesses have defined him, he cannot let them go.  Every decision he makes will benefit his businesses not the country, every tax move, every trade move, every transportation move will be made to benefit his businesses, not the country.  And he has international businesses, so the money going back and forth can seriously break laws that start with the constitution.  I have written about this myself, so when you all see it happen, and it will happen, I can say I told you so!!

Do you really expect 60,000,000 voters, and the Republican Party, to care about his finances?

If they accept his racism, misogyny, narcissism, mendacity and incompetence you can hardly believe they'd draw the line at suspect business dealings before or during his term in Office, could you?

He didn't respect the nation by presenting his tax returns. He told a series of whopping, great lies, and got away with it. Nobody stopped him. Nobody. Not the justice system, not the government and not the people.

The moral cowardice is overwhelming.

Surprise! Donald has NO ethics except to make money and get attention for himself, completely self centered, but an excellent con man. Unfortunately this will be a hate filled divisive administration plus the most corrupt ever. The rules of normalcy do not apply to this man.

replies.commentBody: Get a grip on your propaganda consumption would you?

comments.commentBody: So far Trump, a man with no experience or understanding of the world stage, has already revealed his incompetence during the transition - firing people, papers unsigned, departments waiting for him to be briefed, and bringing in Bannon (who will bring about unrelenting protest from human rights groups). Seems like it will be easy, even inevitable, for Trump to violate the Emoluments Clause. President Bill Clinton was impeached for something as silly as "it depends upon what the meaning of the word 'is' is.

Our best and easiest call is to key in on one or two of numerous inevitable scandals coming which is the easiest for a common person to understand and then tar Trump with it mercilessly, over and over.

Relentlessly sowing doubt in the minds of those who voted for him is the corrosive that will lead to his early departure.

He and his party only know hardball.

Fine.
Batter up.

We may find out very quickly whether Trump's financial interests conflict with those of his working class supporters.  They were willing to apologize for his faults in the campaign because they had become wise to the their betrayal by the Democratic-Republican establishments alliance.  That took decades.  In the age of the internet and "first amendment solutions", the retribution could be fast and furious.  His ego may have lead him to both fool himself and to sucker them.

According to mainstream media, Mr. Trump can hardly manage the transition and will likely to be impeached, etc. If so, the Trump brand will go down with him. Isn't it all his critics want? oh, those news about his transition team and his prospect for success are just rumors to fool us.

The whole idea of running for president, of this incompetent and bankrupt (both morally and economically) make-belief billionaire, is to pull himself out of the financial hole. If he divest it will make it hard to use the presidency for financial gain, so do not hold your breath.

Were the voters that elected Trump really aware of his vast holdings here in the United States and globally?   You are dealing with a huckster who wll not release his tax return or his business holdings and Jared Kushner is  going to help him with  all his investments.  The man doesn't play taxes and boasts about it and yet people voted for him.  He was in the 21 Club and told a patron as he was passing not to worry about him or her paying taxes.  He said he would take care of it.    Ryan will privatized Medicare and Trump will sign the bill.  He will stop federal grants to Medicaid ( god forbid) and Trump will sign it.  Trump does not care for the common person.  We were conned.
Trump will be keeping an eye on his businesses, everyday.  We need to see his full tax returns and all business holdings.
